body.p: The Gentoo Linux 32bits chroot guide will help you setting up a true 32bit chroot for your Gentoo/AMD64 system.

As you know 64bit systems don't run 32bits applications natively yet (at least not with portage) so you need to use emulation libraries to make them working or create a true 32bit system inside a chroot to install and run native 32bit applications. For the most common uses you do not need do build a 32bits chroot system. However, if you want to run applications that don't have a binary available to run with 32bits libraries, you should use a 32bit chroot. This guide will teach you how to set up a 32bit chroot and how to install and run applications inside the chroot.
To install a 32bit chroot you need to follow many footsteps that you use to install Gentoo Linux on a x86 computer. For now you need the latest stage3 available on our mirrors.

pre.caption: downloading stage3 from a gentoo mirror

body.note: Note that we dowload a stage for x86, not for AMD64.
body.p: After downloading the stage3 you need to create a new directory to build your new chroot.
body.pre: $ su root insert your root password # cd /mnt # mkdir gentoo32
body.p: Then move the stage you have already downloaded, unpack it and setup it like this example.
Now you have the chroot ready for setup. Read the next chapter to learn how to set it up.

subsection.title: Doing a setup for your new 32bit chroot

body.p: If everything went well until here now you will be able to set up your new 32bit chroot and finishing installation of this chroot.
The next step is setup your new /mnt/gentoo32/etc/make.conf.
Now mount the various bogus file systems:
body.pre: # mount -o bind /dev /mnt/gentoo32/dev # mount -o bind /dev/pts /mnt/gentoo32/dev/pts # mount -o bind /dev/shm /mnt/gentoo32/dev/shm # mount -o bind /proc /mnt/gentoo32/proc # mount -o bind /proc/bus/usb /mnt/gentoo32/proc/bus/usb # mount -o bind /sys /mnt/gentoo32/sys
body.p: Now you have a true 32bit chroot installed in your 64bits system which is almost ready for use. Next, you need to create a link from your portage available in your 64bit system to your chroot. This way, you only need to update it in one installation instead of duplicating a lot of data.

pre.caption: Link portage to /usr/portage inside the 32bits chroot

body.note: Everytime you update your portage by doing a emerge sync, you update your 32bit chroot's portage as well.
body.p: If you want to run 32bit applications which use X, you also need to mount /tmp.

pre.caption: Mount /tmp for applications with a GUI

body.p: Now we're ready to switch inside the chroot.
body.pre: (Only perform this step if you don't have linux32 already installed) # emerge linux32 # linux32 chroot /mnt/gentoo32 /bin/bash (Make sure we have a i686 setup) # uname -m Linux mysystem 2.6.12-gentoo-r1 #1 Mon Jun 27 02:41:55 GMT 2005 i686 AMD Athlon(tm) 64 Processor 3500+ AuthenticAMD GNU/Linux
body.warn: The linux32 util is needed to change the CHOST value. If you forget it, you're likely to be unable to compile anything inside the chroot environment.
body.p: Now you have a new 32bits chroot system ready to be updated. Follow the next steps to update it.
After this you basically have finished the setup of your 32bits chroot. To make things more suitable, we are going to set up a new file in your 64bit system to enable the 32bits chroot when booting.
Now you only need to run rc-update add gentoo32 default to run it at boot time.
Whenever you want to switch to your chroot environment, you only need to run the following command: linux32 chroot /mnt/gentoo32 /bin/bash.
Now you have your 32bit chroot ready to install new applications.

subsection.title: Installing new applications in your chroot

body.p: Now that you have a fully functional 32bits chroot you can install every application in 32bits mode. Let's see how you can install new packages on your 32bits chroot.
body.pre: # linux32 chroot /mnt/gentoo32 /bin/bash # source /etc/profile # env-update # emerge foo
body.note: Always remember to do source /etc/profile and env-update after switching inside the chroot.
body.p: You now have installed a new package in your 32bit chroot. If you want to run your new package you need to run it inside of your chroot. If you want to run X applications the best solution to run it is doing the xhost trick. Everytime you need to run a X application run the this command in your 64bit environment:
After this get inside your chroot again and you should be able to run every X application you build inside your 32bits chroot.

With this chroot you can install many packages available only for x86 arch. Some packages like OpenOffice can be installed by using the binary available for Gentoo/AMD64. Some of the codecs available for MPlayer need this 32bit chroot to so you can install win32codecs with this chroot.
